etymologies: late Middle English (as an adjective in the sense ‘satisfied’): from Latin saturat- ‘filled, glutted’, from the verb saturare, from satur ‘full’. The early sense of the verb (mid 16th century) was ‘satisfy’; the noun dates from the 1950s

definitions: cause (something) to become thoroughly soaked with water or other liquid so that no more can be absorbed
shortDefinitions: cause something to become thoroughly soaked with water or other liquid so that no more can be absorbed

definitions: cause (a substance) to combine with, dissolve, or hold the greatest possible quantity of another substance

examples.text: the groundwater is saturated with calcium hydroxide

shortDefinitions: cause substance to combine with, dissolve, or hold greatest possible quantity of another substance

definitions: magnetize or charge (a substance or device) fully.
shortDefinitions: magnetize or charge substance or device fully

definitions: put (a device) into a state in which no further increase in current is achievable.
shortDefinitions: put device into state in which no further increase in current is achievable

definitions: fill (something or someone) with something until no more can be held or absorbed

examples.text: the air is saturated with the smells of food

shortDefinitions: fill something or someone with something until no more can be held or absorbed

definitions: supply (a market) beyond the point at which the demand for a product is satisfied

examples.text: Japan's electronics industry began to saturate the world markets

shortDefinitions: supply market beyond point at which demand for product is satisfied

definitions: overwhelm (an enemy target area) by concentrated bombing.
shortDefinitions: overwhelm enemy target area by concentrated bombing

examples.text: as far as the heart is concerned saturates are considered the main enemy
